children.subject: It is sort of in between a seminar and a regular class.  The instructors present results from (mostly recent) papers, although there is not much "discussion" of these; it is a lecture-based class.  This semester we had four problem sets, most of which involved programming in Tensorflow, but a fair amount of starter code was given.
Would you say CS 189 is a good prep for it? Also, how is the workload compared to other classes, say like 189?

Not directly. A few of the assignments require you to implement neural nets but you don't have to take 189 necessarily. Just take a look at the course material lectures: http://rll.berkeley.edu/deeprlcourse/

You could take this course without necessarily knowing 189, if you self-study Stanford's cs 231n that's as good as taking 189, if not better. But I believe the instructor requires you to have taken 189 before you take this class. (Not sure about this though, ask the instructor)
Sorry to bother again. But I am really interested to know whats the workload for this course. This will be my first graduate course so I just want to make sure I plan accordingly.
In you opinion how does the workload of cs 294-112 compare to cs 189?

Waaay less than 189. But beware the final project! It's really what you make out of it. You could just not show up to lectures or watch the webcasts, or alternatively you could actively engage in the class and read lots of papers on your own.
Do you know what the requirements were to get into the class(for undergraduates? Was there like a grade cut off based on how well you did on cs 189?
Please email the professor, I'm not sure.

+1. What is the structure of the class like? Is it a seminar type of class where you read papers and discuss them? Are there regular problem sets? Also, will we use actual libraries (like TensorFlow) or are we implementing everything from scratch.

history.content:
As I mentioned in my blog: I’ve noticed that it has a much different vibe than other classes I’ve taken, in that it isn’t very rigorous and there isn’t much to the course slides or lectures. Rather, the course is just supposed to motivate us to learn more on own, by directing us to read relevant papers on our own. Specifically, this course is focused on using deep learning to make reinforcement learning algorithms more powerful. It comprises of 4 assignments and good knowledge of tensorflow beforehand is recommended but not required. Until the last 4 weeks of the course, there are only technical lectures; the last 4 weeks are guest lectures. Undergraduate students are capable of taking the course. Note that there is a final project at the end and you have to plan this out early!

I encourage you to check out the course website: http://rll.berkeley.edu/deeprlcourse/

Even if you don't get in, the videos are all archived!

Hi,

Is anyone taking this class right now? I am taking CS 189 now and absolutely love it, so I would like to take a grad class on machine learning next semester. This is the most interesting grad class to me about ML, so I would love to hear people's opinions about this class. Thanks!
history.subject: Thoughts on CS 294 - Deep Reinforcement Learning?
